There are $n$ employees and $m$ languages. Each employee knows a set of languages.  Find the minimum amount of money needed to teach each employee all the languages so that any employee can communicate with any other employee (they can communicate indirectly through other employees who know the necessary languages). Each language course costs $1$ dollar. 

Input:

* The first line contains two integers, $n$ and $m$ ($2 \le n, m \le 100$), representing the number of employees and languages.
* The next $n$ lines describe each employee's known languages. 
    * The first number on each line is $k_i$ ($0 \le k_i \le m$), the number of languages the $i$-th employee knows.
    * The following $k_i$ numbers are the identifiers of the languages the $i$-th employee knows.

Output:

* Print a single integer representing the minimum cost to teach all employees all the languages.

You have a group of people and a set of languages. Each person knows some of the languages.  Find the minimum cost to teach each person all the languages so that any person can communicate with any other person (they can communicate indirectly through other people who know the necessary languages).
